title: 110_hr3621
content:
The Act titled "Safety, Accountability, and Funding Efficiency for Transportation Act of 2007" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Act "Safety, Accountability, and Funding Efficiency for Transportation Act of 2007" requires government agencies to conduct cost-benefit analysis before procuring architectural, engineering, and related services from private contractors to ensure safe and cost-effective transportation services. In the Act, definitions for "architectural, engineering, and related services" and "private contract" are provided. The curr_chunk provides definitions for "private contract," "government agency," and "Secretary" in relation to surface transportation projects. The curr_chunk defines "government agency" as a governmental entity receiving Federal funds for surface transportation projects and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Transportation. It also defines "surface transportation project" as projects eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code. The curr_chunk defines a "surface transportation project" as eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code, and related projects as determined by the Secretary of Transportation. The curr_chunk focuses on cost-benefit analysis in relation to surface transportation projects eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code. For surface transportation projects eligible for assistance under title 23, Federal funds can be used for private contracts over $100,000 for architectural, engineering, and related services if a cost-benefit analysis is conducted by the government agency. The analysis must include a description of the services to be performed. A cost-benefit analysis is required for private contracts over $100,000 for surface transportation projects under title 23. The analysis conducted by a government agency must include a description of the services to be performed, estimated costs, and other related expenses. A cost-benefit analysis is required for private contracts over $100,000 for surface transportation projects under title 23. The analysis must include an estimate of the cost of procuring the services, negotiating and awarding the contract, and overseeing the contract. It should also estimate the cost of having the services performed by the government agency, including staff salaries, office facilities, equipment, and other related costs. A cost-benefit analysis is required for private contracts over $100,000 for surface transportation projects under title 23. The analysis includes estimating the cost of services, determining if services would be procured more quickly through a private contract or by the government agency, and considering staff salaries, office facilities, equipment, and related costs. A cost-benefit analysis is required for private contracts over $100,000 for surface transportation projects under title 23. The analysis includes estimating the cost of services, determining if services would be procured more quickly through a private contract or by the government agency, considering staff salaries, office facilities, equipment, and related costs. Additionally, the analysis should include a determination of whether the government agency will provide equipment and materials under the private contract, an estimate of the cost of any such equipment and materials, and an estimate of unemployment compensation or other benefits likely to be paid to employees. (5) Determine if the government agency will provide equipment and materials under the private contract and estimate the cost. 
(6) Estimate the cost of unemployment compensation or benefits for displaced government agency employees. 
(7) Estimate the cost for the government agency to resume performance of the service under the private contract. SEC. 5. DISCLOSURE OF COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS RESULTS: Government agencies must disclose results of cost-benefit analysis for private contracts at least 30 days before entering into the contract. Results must be submitted to the Secretary for review, provided to registered individuals or entities, and made available for public inspection, including online publication. SEC. 6. COMMENTS: Within 15 days of a government agency publishing the results of a cost-benefit analysis for a private contract, employees and interested parties can submit written comments disputing the accuracy of the results. Agency employees can also submit competitive bids to provide the services instead of the contracted party. SEC. 7. USE OF QUALIFICATION-BASED SELECTION CRITERIA. Government agencies must use specific procedures when procuring architectural, engineering, and related services for surface transportation projects using Federal funds. This includes following guidelines outlined in chapter 11 of title 40, United States Code, or equivalent State qualifications-based requirements. SEC. 8. SPECIALTY, EMERGENCY, TEMPORARY WORK. The Secretary may waive the application of this Act for private contracts at the request of a government agency if the work is emergency, specialty, or temporary in nature and cannot be performed by government employees.
